message_1:
In cryptography, a substitution cipher is a method of encrypting a message by replacing the letters of the plaintext with a different set of letters. In order to decrypt the message, one needs to know the substitution key. Suppose you intercept the following ciphertext:
 
ahmjglra hmnrla
 
Assume this ciphertext was encrypted using a substitution cipher with the following key: 
 
a b c d e f g h i j k l m n o p q r s t u v w x y z
r g m c u s i w z e h o f t q d n j p a k l x b y
 
Using cryptanalysis of substitution ciphers, determine the original plaintext message.
message_2:
To decrypt the message, we need to replace each letter in the ciphertext with the corresponding letter in the original alphabet using the given substitution key.

Ciphertext: ahmjglra hmnrla

Substitution key:
a b c d e f g h i j k l m n o p q r s t u v w x y z
r g m c u s i w z e h o f t q d n j p a k l x b y

Using the substitution key, we can decrypt the message as follows:

a -> r
h -> o
m -> w
j -> e
g -> i
l -> s
r -> a
a -> r
h -> o
m -> w
n -> e
r -> a
l -> s
a -> r

Plaintext: rowisear weasar

The original plaintext message is "rowisear weasar".
